climbs.name: Scurf
climbs.fa: Bill Leventhal , Matt Oliphant, Banny Root 1983

content.description:
A classic Route.

Starts on the boulder to very good first couple holds, then holds get smaller and crimpier the higher you go. Crux is 3/4 of the way up.
The crux is 15 feet up traversing up and right on the slippery slab.
content.protection: This is a boulder problem with bad fall consiquences or try to build an anchor. It would be tricky to build a TR anchor for this one. Gear and anchor rope or 50' pieces of webbing, long runners.
content.location: The steep black wall on great holds and pin scars about 15' left of Chimney on the middle of the wall. Ends with traversing up and right on the slippery slab.

content.description: A solid route for the grade, awesome to start your top roping career. Start from the bottom, and make your way stright up past the 2 potholes to the crimp that will elevate you to the top. 2 cruxes, one mantle to get to the first huge pothole (pictured), and then the crimp to take you to the top of the bolts. See pics for the route
content.protection: 2 brand new bolts right at the top, although a bit sketchy getting to them. You can access by walking up the path in Nabisco Canyon, making a left, and walking all the way down the top of that cliff (the top above the traverse)
content.location: Its the left wall around the other side of the traverse, the (left) outer wall of Nabisco canyon

content.description:
hands start on the obvious pockets, work your right hand to the good crimp around right. bump the left hand to the pocket where your right was and throw for the hold up top. fun! could be an iffy landing, bring a pad... preferably a painted one.

VIDEO

youtu.be/Kih9vjp1qQY
content.protection: two pads and an attentive spotter are nice to have.
content.location: up nabisco canyon on the east side. left side of the large boulder at the top. follow maggies traverse past the end. cant miss it.

content.description: Start to the right of East Wall Crack.  Turn right early and take advantage of the two pocket holes.  Above them, you'll veer back left to finish with the hardest moves of the climb.
content.protection: Sling blocks at the top to drop a toprope.
content.location: The start is immediately to the left to East Wall crack, below and to the left of the big holes that you'll want to use.

content.description: Excellent long traverse which starts out on hands with a crux move through a bulging section, after this an easy section, highball initially, to reach the more fingery stuff. The final section constitues the second crux, thin slab moves.
content.protection:
Crashpad, spotters

Video

Scott Nomi on the opening sequence:

vimeo.com/13869681
content.location: The east wall of Nabisco Canyon

content.description:
A powerful and classic route.

An overhanging crack with an awkward start leads to a trending rightwards and a good rest hold.  The face above is problematic to the final pin-scarred crack where the crux lies.
content.protection: Top rope problem - bolts on top.
content.location: Crack on the west wall of Nabisco Canyon.

content.description: Crux is about half way up. Small holds take you past a bulge into a slight depression.
content.protection: Gear anchor. Options for nuts and cams.
content.location: On the east wall of the canyon. Between the tree and the first crack.

content.description: Underclings lead to good holds, which get farther apart as you get closer to the top.
content.protection: Top rope there used to be bolts - not sure now.
content.location: To the left of Skurf - immediately right of the larger cave, step off the boulder.

content.description: fun route that’s worth trying if you have a TR for the other routes close by all set up.  Crux seems impractical but actually flows nicely and doesnt feel too contrived or awkward.
content.protection: Single glue in and cams for TR setup
content.location: In between east wall groove and nabisco.  Crux 2/3 way up.

content.description: Large crack climb with good hand holds most of the way up. Crux is the near the top with slight overhang.
content.protection:
Top Rope

1 bolt and 1 wrap around boulder

content.description: Take the pin-scarred crack up then pull onto the face above, trend up and slightly left (crux) on slopy footholds and small handholds toward the anchor used for RH Route.
content.protection: Jammed chockstone in a chimney behind the wall and cams.
content.location: To the right of RH Route - the right diagonal pin-scarred crack of Maggies Traverse.

content.description: Climb the chimney on the right end of the wall.
